title: Human Rights Atlas
abstractText: This projects collates and assembles cross-national time-series data for all countries in the world between 1981 and 2011 on basic country conditions, legal commitments and human rights practices. The main data set is used to construct a series of comparable categorical scales for an interactive web-interface that uses global maps. The atlas data are to be plotted for the whole world and visualised over time. The data are all in the public domain and include over 200 indicators for over 200 countries and territories for the period 1981-2011.
impactText: The atlas provides a use friendly resource for global data on country performance, legal commitments and human rights protection. The tool has been used for education, research and knowledge exchange. The data have appeared in education programmes, peer reviewed journal articles, and training workshops with scholars and practitioners. findingsText: We have learned how to write code that visualises cross-country and time series data using global maps. We have learned about the spatial and temporal diffusion of human rights globally. We have learned how data and data visualisation can be used for teaching, research and engagement with the policy world. The data will be shared free of charge and the atlas will remain as a tool for us and others to engage in human rights measurement issues.
